conclusion: A basketball is dropped from a height H and rebounds to a height h after an inelastic collision with the ground.
Air resistance is proportional to the gravitational force, with a proportionality constant λ, where 0 < λ < (H - h)/(H + h).
The ratio of post-collision velocity to pre-collision velocity is the same for each collision with the ground.
The goal is to find the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity.
The basketball is dropped from rest at height H, so its initial velocity is zero.
The basketball falls under gravity, experiences air resistance on the way down, hits the ground, and then bounces back up, again experiencing air resistance, to a new height h.

m is the mass of the basketball, g is the acceleration due to gravity, v_down is the velocity just before hitting the ground, v_up is the velocity just after rebounding from the ground, e = v_up/v_down is the coefficient of restitution.
The net force acting on the basketball during descent is F_net, down = mg - λmg = mg(1 - λ).
The acceleration during descent is a_down = g(1 - λ).
During the collision with the ground, the basketball's velocity changes from v_down to -v_up.
The net force during ascent is F_net, up = -mg - λmg = -mg(1 + λ).
The acceleration during ascent is a_up = -g(1 + λ).
